title: On NTSB recommendations, FAA closes helicopter route near DC airport weeks after tragedy
author: MENNATALLA IBRAHIM Capital News Service
content: Following the Jan. 29 midair collision that killed 67 people, the NTSB issued urgent safety recommendations, and Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy accepted them, saying “And why this information wasn't studied and known before January 29 is an important question.” The NTSB’s preliminary report notes that the investigation remains in “the fact‑finding phase,” and cautions that the helicopter route over the Potomac River must be closed while alternatives are sought. Duffy criticized the current air‑traffic‑control system and said, “We're at a point where we can do this fast—three and a half to four years for a brand new air traffic control system. Gold plated. Envy of the world,” promising a rapid upgrade. He added, “It will greatly improve our safety…but it's also going to improve the efficiency that we have in American air travel, which I think will mean less delays, less cancellations, and again, better safety.” Meanwhile, NTSB Chair Jennifer Homendy has said the investigation will continue to “determine what happened…the how and why,” reassuring travelers that “aviation is incredibly safe” while acknowledging the need for improvements.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on aviation safety recommendations, regulatory actions, and accident prevention, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Oxford to install three-way stop on Tilghman Street - Town considering traffic study to address speeding concerns
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content: Town of Oxford will install a three‑way stop at the intersection of Tilghman and Bank to curb speeding, with Commissioner Tom Costigan noting, “A three‑way stop. Let’s see if that works.” Will Cawley presented 13‑day speed data and urged a speed study, while Police Chief Eric Kellner highlighted pedestrian safety, saying, “Sidewalks would be a great thing to look at. But I also know that putting in sidewalks is not as easy as saying, ‘We want a sidewalk.’” Costigan added, “It’s not an easy process,” and continued, “But it’s one we can certainly look into and try,” while acknowledging that the stop signs would give drivers time to adjust before summer traffic. The town will follow the stop with an education period, and Costigan added, “They may even like it.” The town may also conduct a $3,100 speed study in summer to refine recommendations.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses traffic safety measures, speed violations, and a town's plan to install stop signs and conduct a speed study, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: September declared National Preparedness Month
content: The Talbot County Council declared September National Preparedness Month, with Brian LeCates, director of Emergency Services, and Geneva Schaffle, division chief of Emergency Management, accepting the proclamation on August 22. Schaffle stressed the timing of the announcement, noting, "We are approaching hurricane season, and this week has been very active, so we thought it was a great time to remind the community the importance of preparedness," and added, "Our county works really hard with all of our stakeholders to prepare all year long but there are a couple of things people can do to be prepared." She also urged residents to review their insurance, saying, "This is also the time to pull out your insurance policies, know what is in your insurance policy and make sure you are prepared for our storm season as we come to a peak here in September," and highlighted the Department of Emergency Services’ resources such as ready.gov, talbotalerts.com, and the DES website. The county’s Planning and Zoning Office offers a Community Rating System that can reduce flood insurance premiums, and DES is hosting a seven‑week Community Disaster Response Course with only three spots remaining. County Manager Clay Stamp summed up the effort, stating, "An informed community is a strong community," and adding, "The key is to connect with Emergency Services today, on a sunny day, so that when the storm clouds come in, you are connected and get timely information and we can respond to help."

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on emergency preparedness, alerts, and disaster response training, which are core public safety issues, though it also mentions a county council proclamation, linking it to local government.

people: Brian LeCates, director of Emergency Services
Geneva Schaffle, division chief of Emergency Management

title: Toddlers drown in incident in Greensboro on Sunday
author: STAFF REPORT
content: Two toddlers, a 2‑year‑old and a 3‑year‑old, drowned in Greensboro on Sunday, June 29, according to a press release from the Caroline County Sheriff’s Office. Deputies responded at about 7:30 p.m. to the 12000 block of Greensboro Road and found the children being treated by the Caroline County Department of Emergency Services and the Greensboro Volunteer Fire Department before they were transported to Shore Regional Health in Easton, where they ultimately died. The Sheriff’s Office says a criminal investigation is underway and has not released further details. “The Caroline County Sheriff's Office extends its deepest condolences to the family and all those affected by this heartbreaking tragedy,” the press release said.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a drowning incident involving toddlers and details the response by sheriff's deputies, emergency services, and fire department, which aligns most closely with public safety concerns.

organizations: Caroline County Department of Emergency Services

title: Dundalk residents view crumpled bridge with shock, dismay
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content: After a container ship slammed into the Francis Scott Key Bridge, residents were stunned, with Santana recalling that the impact felt “As if something had exploded,” and adding that “It was scary because it could have been us.”  The sight drew frequent exclamations of “Shock” and “Shock and dismay,” and Corkhum noted that “Nobody in a million years thought we would wake up this morning to something like that,” adding that the event “It brings back emotions from 9/11. … You saw that and the first thing you think is, ‘Oh my god. The people. The workers.’”  Her friend’s son, a truck driver, “literally just got over the bridge before it happened,” and she herself “said, ‘I was having a heart attack this morning thinking he was out on the road last night,’.”  Meeks, a Dundalk native, said, “The Key Bridge is a very iconic piece of Dundalk,” and that it is “something that everybody who's from Dundalk or this city even has at one point in their life crossed,” noting that “It could make my trips be a lot longer” and that “Because it's like you don't really expect these kinds of tragedies and stuff to happen and occur in your neighborhood.”  The Historical Society called the collapse “unbelievable,” with Stadler saying “It takes a while to fathom it,” and Walker noting the bridge’s history and that its founder was “instrumental”; “It’s the backdrop for everything around here,” added Stadler, while Corkhum lamented, “I’m so used to seeing that pretty view out there every day,” adding, “It’s going to be horrible seeing that (there's) no view anymore.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a sudden bridge collapse, emergency response, and resident safety concerns, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Cambridge man handed two life sentences without parole
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content: Tramelle Williams was handed two consecutive life sentences without parole for the murders of Taijay Daniels and Lory Fields, after a judge described the footage of Daniels’ death as “possibly in the top five, if not No. 2 most difficult thing I’ve had to see.”  The state argued a motion for a new trial should be denied because the evidence “clearly supported a conviction on all counts,” adding that “‘Taijay Daniels’ would be nothing more than a ‘John Doe’ to the seated jurors.”  Judge William Jones confirmed that jurors had been told to disregard any mention of Daniels, noting “And they did.”  Families spoke at the hearing: Daniels’ mother called him “full of love,” and Fields’ daughter lamented, “I have been so lost without you.”  Williams also received an additional 20‑year robbery sentence and two 20‑year firearms sentences.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal case, sentencing, and court proceedings, which are core aspects of public safety reporting.

title: Cambridge man charged with kidnapping in connection to missing woman
author: Natalie Jones
content: Kenneth Stefan Bradley, 41, was arrested for kidnapping a missing 31‑year‑old woman, Tiyavauna Britt, who has not been found. Police say a cousin heard Bradley and Britt arguing and that a man “started to assault” her after she was taken to a dark Chevrolet Suburban, with voices recorded in the footage. Officers later observed the driver “carrying and dragging” a small statured, light‑skinned female into the vehicle and placing her “limp body” in the rear cargo area before leaving at 8:30 p.m. The car was found unlocked with Britt’s belongings and a note, and prior incidents show a history of violence between Bradley and the victim. Bradley is currently on probation, has a previous assault conviction, and is scheduled for a preliminary hearing on March 12.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a kidnapping, police investigation, and criminal charges, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Police Team With Talbot Optimist Club For Shop With A Cop
author: Contributed
content: The Easton, Oxford, and Talbot County police departments teamed up with the Talbot Optimist Club for a “Shop with a Cop” holiday gift event, pairing officers with local youths to buy presents for their families.  As organizer Debbie Henckel explained, “It's all about the kids, the smiles on their faces, and them being able to have something to give to their families,” and said the event is meant to let children give back.  Chief Alan Lowrey praised the generosity, noting, “I've seen these kids looking out for their families instead of themselves, our officers reaching into their own wallets to make sure no one is left out, and even just some local townspeople going out of their way to do the same. It is really moving, and I'm proud to see it all.”  Henckel added that she often sees familiar returning officers, saying, “You see a lot of returning officers and you know that's because they care. It's nice to see their eagerness to be here with the kids,” and that “They really make a difference to these kids, and around our community.”  Finally, she thanked the partners and added, “ To have their support over the years means more than you know.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a police‑led community outreach event where officers partner with a local youth club to provide holiday gifts, which directly relates to public safety and community policing activities.

people: Chief Alan Lowrey, Talbot County Police Department

title: Demolition of remaining Key Bridge structures beginning around July 7
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@chespub.com
content: The Maryland Transportation Authority announced on June 26 that demolition of the remaining Key Bridge structures will begin around July 7 and is expected to take several months. The process will first remove the bridge deck over the river, then demolish sections over Hawkins Point and Sollers Point, with no controlled detonations. The demolition will also strip deck, barriers, parapets, girders, piers, and ultimately the north and south abutments, using excavators, concrete saws, vacuums, cranes, trucks, and an on‑site concrete crusher to recycle materials. Nearby communities will see tug and barge operations, heavy equipment, and safety buoys, with typical construction noise from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. and baseline noise/vibration monitoring already underway; speed restrictions and safety zones will be posted to protect vessels and the public. The Authority will continue to update on any impacts and has requested permit modifications and a categorical exclusion reevaluation to reflect changes in pier design and environmental effects.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on demolition activities, safety zones, noise and vibration monitoring, and public advisories, making public safety the most relevant category.

title: Accessible AED added in Downtown Easton
author: Contributed
content: The city of Easton has installed its first 24‑hour publicly accessible AED station downtown, located on Washington Street next to Doc's Downtown Grille, and it includes an AED, a Stop the Bleed tourniquet kit, and opioid overdose kits. Rachael Cox, a special programs paramedic for Talbot Emergency Services, said, "We are incredibly proud of this station.It's the first time we've been able to place a station that is accessible 24 hours a day, outside of a public park or recreation area," underscoring the partnership between Talbot CARES, Bluepoint Hospitality, and the Talbot Paramedic Foundation. The station will be routinely stocked and checked by DES, while Bluepoint’s security head Michael Smith added, "One of our priorities is for visitors and residents to feel safe downtown," noting that many staff were certified in CPR and first aid to support the initiative. The project marks a significant step in making life‑saving equipment available to the community at any time.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on the installation of a publicly accessible AED and related emergency equipment to improve community safety, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic, though it also relates to health.

people: Rachael Cox, special programs paramedic, Talbot Emergency Services
Michael Smith, security head, Bluepoint Hospitality

title: Plane crashes during landing at Bay Bridge Airport
author: Staff Writer
content: A four‑seat Cirrus aircraft crashed while attempting to land at Bay Bridge Airport in Stevensville on April 30, 2025. The plane veered off the runway into a marshy area, partially sinking into the water, but the sole occupant was not injured, according to Beth Malasky, public information manager for Queen Anne’s County. Fire and EMS crews cleared the scene shortly after noon, and federal and state aviation authorities are en route to conduct a standard investigation. Malasky also noted there is no damage to the runway; however, the airport will remain closed until the investigation is complete.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a local aircraft crash and the emergency response, which falls squarely under public safety concerns.

people: Beth Malasky, public information manager for Queen Anne’s County

title: The Star Democrat's top 10 online stories this week
author: STAFF REPORT
content: The Star Democrat’s weekly “top 10 online stories” list ranks the most‑viewed local news items. The highest‑viewed story is the death of Easton High School graduate Darren Foxwell in a car crash, followed by a body that “sat in the yard for upwards of four hours” in Greensboro due to traffic delays. Other top stories include a serious rollover crash outside Trappe that left a passenger with life‑threatening injuries, an Easton man killed in an Anne Arundel County crash, and a car flip on Route 16 in Cambridge with no injuries. The list also notes arrests linked to an Easton bank robbery, the opening of a second Molly’s Place store in Easton, the reopening of St. Michaels’ Blue Crab Coffee Shop under new owners, a man pleading guilty to attempted murder in a Trappe gas‑station shooting, and Easton coach Keenan stepping down to watch his youngest sons play collegiate sports.

llm_classification.explanation: The article lists top local stories, most of which involve accidents, police investigations, and crime incidents, which align best with the Public Safety category.

title: 2 charged with hindering drug investigation, reporting fake shooting in Easton
author: Konner Metz
content: Police arrested Elon Black, 38, of Easton, and Lacira Wilson, 39, of Worton, for hindering a drug investigation and filing a fake 911 report of a shooting at the Easton Walmart. The pair were charged on September 18 and 19 with intent to distribute drugs, obstructing and hindering, and making false statements to police officers after a traffic stop on April 4 revealed “suspected heroin/fentanyl mix,” crack cocaine and ecstasy during a K‑9 search. Black called Wilson, who then called 911 and reported a shooting that did not occur, prompting officers to find no evidence of gunfire at the Walmart. Both defendants posted unsecured $10,000 bonds; Wilson’s trial is set for November 5 in Talbot County District Court, and Black’s for November 3 in District Court. Black also faces additional felony, misdemeanor and traffic counts from the same stop, with a jury trial scheduled for December 8.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on police arrests, criminal charges, and a false emergency report, which are matters of law enforcement and community safety, fitting the Public Safety category best.

title: Gallatin County Sheriff's Office welcomes public to tour new building at Four Corners
author: Laurenz Busch Chronicle Staff Writer
content: Sheriff Dan Springer hosted a public tour of the new 25,000‑sq‑ft Gallatin County Sheriff’s Office building in Four Corners, a facility that cost $5.4 million and sits on 6.48 acres. He explained that “There wasn’t enough money to build a facility, which had been the plan to build our Sheriff’s Office up by the jail,” and that “Since we couldn’t do that, there wasn’t that kind of money available, so we ended up remodeling this to make it more fiscally responsible.” The new location offers three shooting ranges and expanded office space, though Springer notes “We train a lot in shooting, but when you look at the big picture, it’s (mostly) traffic stops and domestic responses,” and that the ranges were “the bonus to the facility. The primary objective when we purchased this was the fact that it’s 6.48 acres, in the middle of Four Corners, which is where we’re growing and where our primary routes are.” The building’s strategic position within a nine‑mile radius of most calls helps deputies avoid traffic on 19th Avenue and Huffine Lane, and Springer highlighted that 70% of calls occur within that zone. The tour also included memorials for fallen deputies and a glimpse of future expansions such as a search‑and‑rescue building and a larger training campus.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the county sheriff's office, its new building, law‑enforcement operations and public tours, which are core aspects of public safety. It also involves county officials, linking it to local government, but public safety is the primary theme.

people: Sheriff Dan Springer, Gallatin County Sheriff

title: Automotive Group gives $300,000 to first responder training campus
author: Contributed
content: The Preston Automotive Group donated $300,000 to the Friends of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department for a new Emergency Services Training Campus in Easton. President David Wilson Jr. praised the project, saying “Preston Automotive Group is proud to support an amazing project that will benefit the first responders in our local counties firsthand,” and adding “We are grateful to have so many brave men and women putting their lives on the line daily to make sure we are all safe. These men and women are the backbone of our community, the least we could do is contribute to a facility that will help train them and give them the resources they need to be as prepared as possible for situations that come their way while protecting us.” Co‑chairman Brett Whitehead highlighted the campus’s purpose, noting “We train together because we answer the call together,” and that “The donation from the Preston Automotive Group is an essential first step toward ensuring training available for all emergency services in Talbot County, including our volunteer firefighters, our law enforcement and our emergency services personnel and paramedics. The demand for these services continues to grow on the Mid‑Shore and this training campus will help meet this critical need.” The facility—located at 9095 Mistletoe Drive—includes a 3,500‑square‑foot public safety building, a 3,600‑square‑foot classroom and storage building, and a 1,500‑square‑foot concrete pad for motor‑vehicle and traffic safety training, and will serve fire, law‑enforcement, and EMS personnel across the Mid‑Shore.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a donation to support training for fire, law enforcement, and EMS personnel, which directly relates to public safety services.

people: David Wilson Jr., President, Preston Automotive Group
Brett Whitehead, Co-chairman, Friends of the Easton Volunteer Fire Department

title: Dead body found in Walmart parking lot in Denton
author: Konner Metz
content: A dead body was found inside a vehicle in the parking lot of a Walmart in Denton on Wednesday afternoon. Police chief George Bacorn said the department received a call just before 3 p.m. and that they discovered the body in the lot. The investigation is ongoing, and Bacorn noted there is "no indication of foul play." The cause of death has not yet been determined, and authorities are awaiting findings from the medical examiner’s office. The victim’s name has not been released by the Denton Police Department as of Friday.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a police investigation of a dead body found in a public parking lot, which falls under public safety/crime reporting.

title: 2-structure fire causes $850,000 in damage
author: Tom McCall
content: On August 21, firefighters responded to a two‑structure, two‑alarm fire on Stone Boundary Road, which caused $850,000 in total damage: $600,000 for the destroyed former butcher shop and adjacent wooden‑frame farmhouse and $250,000 for their contents. Seventy‑five firefighters spent three hours to control the blaze, with the Tanker Task Force providing extra water. The incident resulted in no deaths or injuries, and no smoke alarms were present in either building. According to the fire marshal’s report, "The fire originated inside the butcher shop shortly after the owner had been doing work inside. Embers from this fire landed on the cedar shingles of the vacant nearby 100+ year old home eventually spreading to the remainder of the house. Both structures are considered a total loss." Both buildings were declared a total loss.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a two-structure fire, the emergency response by firefighters, and safety details, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: After The Storm
content: The Star Democrat’s “After The Storm” story, dated September 4, 2023, focuses on the aftermath of Hurricane Idalia in Horseshoe Beach, Florida. A photograph by Rebecca Blac Kwell shows a baby looking out the window of a truck as it navigates storm‑damaged roads on August 30, 2023. The article emphasizes the community’s resilience and the ongoing recovery efforts following the hurricane. No direct quotations appear in the piece.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on storm damage and a hurricane, which are matters of public safety and emergency response, making Public Safety the most appropriate category.

title: Human trafficking expert hired by For All Seasons
content: For All Seasons, part of Maryland’s Regional Navigator Program, has hired Susan Ahlstrom as a human trafficking navigator to better serve victims under 24 on the Mid‑Shore. Ahlstrom, a mental‑health counselor with 25 years of nonprofit experience and a Master of Science in Counseling, said: “I hope to help mitigate the upward trend in Human Trafficking by expanding For All Seasons Rape Crisis Center's outreach; and strengthening the medical, legal, social service, and mental health collaboration that has already been established to support survivors.I believe my counseling and education background, along with strong communication and networking skills will help facilitate the most effective trauma-informed response to serve victims and their families in the Mid‑Shore region and beyond,” Ahlstrom said. She will coordinate with experts statewide to strengthen support networks and use her EFT/tapping skills to assist survivors. The article explains that the Eastern Shore’s transportation links and seasonal economy make it a hotspot for trafficking, urging communities to learn how to identify victims. The organization invites people to learn more or request a presentation at WeSupportSurvivors.org or by emailing Ahlstrom.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on human trafficking, a criminal activity and victim support, which falls under public safety concerns. It also mentions a state‑run program and local coordination, making Local Government a secondary relevance.

organizations: For All Seasons Rape Crisis Center

title: 'We made a big impact' - Greensboro PD's Trams promoted, Chief Paugh joins Sheriff's Office
author: Connie Connolly; cconnolly@chespub.com
content: During an informal ceremony, Chief George Paugh promoted Lenox Trams to lieutenant and praised him, saying, “I was recruited here to make a difference and reinstate the love for law enforcement, so I've been trying to do that for seven months, and I'm going to continue to do that. It's a great little town.” Trams responded, “I'm going to stay and watch this thing grow, and continue to give excellent service to the citizens and the town.” The town manager, Tammy Kelledes, added, “We're very proud to have you, and you're doing a fantastic job,” while Paugh thanked attendees, saying, “I want to thank you guys for taking your time out of your busy Monday to join Lenox on his special day. It's been a long time coming.” Paugh also reflected on Trams’ brief but impactful tenure, noting, “Even though it's been a short period of time in Greensboro, you definitely made an impact in the community,” and added, “I'm always stopped and told about how well you're doing and how you interact with the community, and that's huge. And that's who you are. You're Mr. Community Policeman,” before concluding, “You've done some amazing things, and you're worthy of the rank.” He also highlighted the department’s upgrades, stating, “We made a big impact,” and “We got a new CAD (computer-aided dispatch) system, new body cameras, new in-car cameras, all new computer systems.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a police officer's promotion and the police chief's career move, which are matters of law enforcement and community safety, fitting the Public Safety category best.

people: Chief George Paugh, Greensboro Police Department
Lieutenant Lenox Trams, Greensboro Police Department

title: Officer fights to deter drivers like one who injured him
author: LYDIA HURLEY Capital News Service
content: After losing both legs in a 2023 attack, Montgomery County officer Sgt. Patrick Kepp vowed to push new reckless‑driving laws, saying, “I will be there in Annapolis to make sure these bills happen,” as he travels from Walter Reed for rehabilitation. Delegates plan to name the proposal the “Sgt. Pat Kepp Bill on Reckless Driving,” and have called Kepp a “hero,” while lawmakers cite “overall frustration” with current enforcement. The legislation would widen the definition of reckless driving and add penalties, with Kepp noting it will “give a little more teeth to some of our laws” and “will strengthen our laws and make our roadways safer,”. The bills also aim to curb “exhibition driving” and other high‑risk behaviors, stressing that “It's way too easy for a driver to just pay a fine and get back on the road and do what they were doing before,”. As Elrich warns, “All it takes is a moment's loss of control over that vehicle,” and “Instead of being entertaining, it would take little to transform it into a deadly incident.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a police officer's injury from reckless driving and his push for new traffic safety legislation, which directly relates to public safety concerns.

people: Sgt. Patrick Kepp, Montgomery County Police Department
places: Walter Reed Army Medical Center, Maryland

title: CPR training for 911 calls could expand statewide
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content: Tony Rose, the chief of 911 for Charles County, was authorized to testify on House Bill 1092, a proposal that would require the Maryland 911 Board to establish CPR training standards for call‑center personnel and use the 911 Trust Fund to cover the cost of such training. Rose praised a virtual training program that requires a scenario every three months, stating, “The results have been phenomenal,” and adding, “We have doubled, and in some cases tripled, the number of survivors of out‑of‑hospital cardiac arrest in Charles County. They're walking out of a hospital after they've stopped breathing.” He also cited a written testimony noting improved bystander CPR and AED use and a rise in survivors discharged: “We also reported that we had improved the application of bystander CPR from 27% to 43%, improved bystander application of an AED from 23.5% to 28.6% and saw the number of survivors that were discharged from the hospital increase from five to eleven.” Commissioner Ralph E. Patterson II recalled a cardiac‑arrest incident to highlight the importance of the legislation. Rose added that, “Currently, Charles County is the only jurisdiction that participates in this program,” and that the bill would make it mandatory for 911 centers to provide, not necessarily this particular program, but one similar to it.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses legislation and training for 911 operators to provide CPR instructions, focusing on emergency response and public safety infrastructure.

people: Tony Rose, Chief of 911 for Charles County
Commissioner Ralph E. Patterson II, Commissioner

title: Mid-Shore sheriffs join in call for DJS secretary's resignation
author: KONNER METZ kmetz@chespub.com
content: Sheriffs across Maryland urged Gov. Wes Moore to “immediately demand the resignation” of Vincent Schiraldi, citing a letter that states “Since Schiraldi’s appointment in 2022, his extreme policies and lack of leadership as the Secretary of the Department of Juvenile Services, have directly made communities less safe in Maryland,” and that “Consistently in Maryland, juveniles have been charged with serious violent crimes.”  While the governor’s office notes “over the past year,” a “26% decline in juvenile homicide arrests and 46% decline in non‑fatal shootings of juveniles” and that “The governor is fully committed to working with local elected officials, law enforcement, the judiciary, and community leaders to improve public safety by holding youth accountable and rehabilitating them,” Schiraldi says he will “stay in his job” and argues “He’s gotten us additional funds this year — $17 million to make community safer by expanding programs — and I want those community members who are calling for my resignation to feel safe.”  Sheriff James Phillips recalled the secretary “had the audacity to tell us, … 'The data that I’m receiving doesn’t support your claim of increased juvenile crime,'" and that “And our reply to that was, ‘Well, obviously the numbers are going to be down because you’re not allowing us to charge (them) anymore.’”  He added that “we’re dealing with the same people, the same names, the same age kids,” and that “The law‑abiding citizens are suffering because of their ignorance and stupidity in protecting these criminals,” noting “And that’s all they are. They might only be 15 or 16, but they’re thugs.”  Joe Gamble praised a “good” Teen Court, saying “They’re getting more community service and stuff out of Teen Court than they would ever get out of DJS,” but called the system “just a failed system. And it’s being led by what the Sheriffs’ Association believes …” while Donnie Baker decried the Child Interrogation Protection Act as a “shame when parental rights are superseded by the legislature,” stating the General Assembly has a “role to play” and that “Juvenile reform needs to be a high priority to help take the steps needed for them to have accountability for when they step into adulthood.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on law‑enforcement officials (sheriffs) demanding the resignation of a state juvenile services secretary due to concerns about juvenile crime and community safety, making public safety the most fitting category.

people: Gov. Wes Moore, Governor of Maryland
Vincent Schiraldi, Secretary of the Department of Juvenile Services

title: For All Seasons gives update on human trafficking in Talbot County
author: Konner Metz
content: Lauren Weber, For All Seasons’ vice president of strategy and development, reminded the Talbot County Council that “It is happening and it's happening here. That continues to be the case,” and that “… There's a complexity to human trafficking that it doesn't really know county boundaries.” She described the situation as a “double-edged sword,” noting that “A year ago we sat in front of you and said, when we look at our rape crisis center data, a good fifth of what was coming in was having at least one indicator of human trafficking,” and that “… That persists.” Weber also observed a shift in reporting, saying “The folks that are self-referring, we're seeing a decline,” but “But we're seeing a real rapid incline in folks coming to us and saying, 'Hey, I know more and now I've seen something.'” At the meeting’s conclusion, council Vice President Pete Lesher thanked the organization, saying, “We appreciate all that you do both on prevention, but also to develop and take care of those who have been victims.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses human trafficking, a crime and safety concern addressed by a nonprofit and county council, making Public Safety the most relevant category.

people: Lauren Weber, For All Seasons’ vice president of strategy and development
Pete Lesher, Vice President, Talbot County Council

title: Suspect still at large following police pursuit
content: A suspect, Todd Randall Hockensmith, 36, of Felton, was still at large Tuesday morning after a pursuit that began on Friday, Aug. 25 near Marydel, Maryland, in which Delaware and Maryland police chased him through Caroline County before he fled into a wooded area.  After a three‑hour search with K‑9 and aviation units, authorities could not locate him, while a vehicle he drove had been reported stolen to the Denton Police Department.  “The vehicle was reported stolen to the Denton Police Department by Hertrich Chevrolet (in Denton), and we actually located another vehicle on the property that was stolen from them that they didn't even know about,” Baker said.  Meanwhile, a female associate of Hockensmith, Danyeal L. Shahan, was arrested and charged with motor‑vehicle theft; she is wanted through Delaware and is being held on bond at the Caroline County Detention Center.  “The Caroline County Sheriff's Office has active warrants for Hockensmith 'for the two motor vehicle deaths (of) two brand new cars from Hertrich Chevrolet here in Denton,'” Baker said, and he also “has three active felony warrants for his arrest for a host of offenses, including theft, burglary and a police pursuit.”  The investigation remains open, and anyone with information is asked to contact the sheriff’s office at 410‑479‑2515.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on an ongoing police pursuit, suspect search, and law‑enforcement actions, which are core aspects of public safety reporting.

title: Icy roads, school closures continue into Thursday
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content: Snow has blanketed the Eastern Shore since Monday, and county officials say they expect the roads to be cleared by Thursday. Town of Easton crews, led by engineer Rick Van Emburgh, have been salting all back roads, prioritizing emergency routes like those to the hospital, and say that back roads “had been plowed twice and now their focus is salting to prevent from freezing.” Superintendent Mark Chandler of Denton’s public works reported that all town roads were passable on Wednesday but urged residents to drive carefully. Schools across the region remain closed, with Talbot County Public Schools announcing a Thursday closure “due to the continued treacherous road conditions in some parts of the county,” and noting that four inclement‑weather days are already built into the 2024‑25 calendar. Dorchester County and Caroline County Public Schools also closed Thursday, each citing a built‑in number of snow days that will not shift the year‑end.

llm_classification.explanation: The article primarily reports on hazardous icy road conditions and the resulting safety advisories, which aligns with Public Safety. It also mentions actions by town officials (Local Government) and school closures (Education), but safety is the central focus.

title: Residents displaced in 2-house fire
author: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com
content: Leona Demdy, 87, lost most of her belongings when a Saturday afternoon blaze destroyed her 27‑year home at 17 South Locust Lane in Easton, Maryland. She said her photographs were what she would miss the most, stating, “I cried, cried, cried,” and later, “I had everybody's picture on the wall. My walls were just full of pictures.” The fire also engulfed the neighboring house, but both residents escaped without serious injury. Seven local volunteer fire departments, along with EMS and law enforcement, responded and contained the blaze after a little more than two hours. The state fire marshal is investigating the cause; damages are significant, both houses are displaced, and Demdy is staying with a relative near Salisbury.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a residential fire, emergency response, and displacement of residents, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: The Star Democrat's top 10 online stories this week
author: STAFF REPORT
content: The Star Democrat’s top 10 online stories for the week blend local crime, community events, and notable incidents. The list opens with police seeking help to identify a suspect in a bank robbery, followed by the discovery of human remains during a Cherrywood Solar construction site and a serious Route 50 crash that injured four people. Additional headlines cover a fatal shooting in Queen Anne’s, the removal of Talbot and Queen Anne’s from a Trump “sanctuary jurisdictions” list, graduation celebrations at Easton and St. Michaels high schools, and a 12‑year‑old middle‑schooler who became the youngest to publish a fantasy novel, titled “Hero of Draconis.” The remaining stories include the removal of a beloved tile wall at Idlewild Park, a NTSB transcript about the Dali ship collapse, and a community rally for a retired teacher after a tornado.

llm_classification.explanation: The majority of the listed stories involve police investigations, crimes, accidents, and emergency responses, which align most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Students complete inaugural Talbot County Sheriff's Office police academy
author: Konner Metz
content: Students in grades 10‑12 graduated from Talbot County’s inaugural citizens police academy, a 10‑week program that offered hands‑on lessons in crisis response, bleeding emergencies and traffic stops. Saints Peter & Paul sophomore Carson Tyree remarked, “What stood out is how these guys work. It’s not all fun and games,” adding, “… When they go into a situation, there’s a lot of thinking behind it because they can’t violate procedure. If they violate procedure, they can’t be a police officer.” Junior Jules Stepp said, “It was like we were there with them,” and “We got to live vicariously through them,” noting she was “surprised how much detail went into every little thing, and how one little thing can cause a problem so they had to backtrack and think about what the consequences could be.” Lt. J.R. Dobson observed, “I think from day one — when (Sheriff Joe Gamble) was giving you guys a lesson on when the first sheriff of Talbot County was — until now, I’ve seen you all loosen up.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a citizens police academy run by the Sheriff's Office, focusing on law‑enforcement training and community safety, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

people: Carson Tyree, sophomore, Saints Peter & Paul
Jules Stepp, junior, Saints Peter & Paul

title: Man gets five years for Thanksgiving Day stabbing of stepson
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content: A man, Ernest Anthony Vuocolo, was sentenced to five years in prison after a trial for stabbing his adult stepson on Thanksgiving night in November 2023. The judge, Cameron A. Brown, suspended all but four years of a ten‑year second‑degree assault sentence, added a one‑year dangerous‑weapon term and a concurrent four‑year reckless endangerment sentence. Court records say the incident was a “physical domestic involving a knife,” and deputies recovered a knife described as “thick blade,” at the Stirrup Drive residence. The stepson was taken to Christiana Hospital for a stab wound after the victim—who had claimed Vuocolo made “sexual comments”—was held in a headlock by Vuocolo. Vuocolo maintained that he acted in self‑defense, citing medical issues and a 20‑year age gap.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal incident, court sentencing, and police involvement, which are core aspects of public safety reporting.

title: Weekend storm threatens Shore with rain, wind
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content:
The Eastern Shore is bracing for a coastal storm that will build late Saturday, bringing 1‑3 inches of rain and winds up to 40 mph.  
Meteorologist Zack Cooper explained that “So really starting late in the day Saturday we’ll start to see an increase in cloud cover and shower activity, which will ramp up rapidly from there going into Sunday, which is when most of the heavy rainfall will occur, Sunday into Sunday night and going into Monday as well,” and warned of possible minor flooding.  
He added that “A lot of times if there’s minor flooding or roadway flooding or things like that the best course of action is to just stay off the roadways,” urging residents to avoid affected roads.  
The MDTA has issued wind warnings and possible bridge holds from Sunday into Monday, and the National Weather Service will continue to monitor the storm.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on an upcoming coastal storm, emphasizing weather warnings, potential flooding, and traffic restrictions, which are primarily concerns of public safety.

title: State looks to clear out homeless camp near highway
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content: The Maryland State Highway Administration invited contractors to bid on a clean‑up contract for a homeless encampment on Crain Highway near Waldorf, where the contract states, "Contractor shall provide all labor and expertise for surveying, documenting, clean‑up, collecting, removal, and disposal services involving homeless encampment abatement actions on MDOT SHA property located in Charles County under an 'as needed' agreement basis," and adds that "The site must be restored to a condition without obvious evidence of previous human habitation,". A local agency spokesperson, Corae Young, said, "I believe what occurred is people moved close by," after noting the camp had been cleared a year ago. Daniel Allman of SHA explained that the agency "SHA works in partnership with local agencies, including support and outreach services and law enforcement, to assist those residing on state rights‑of‑way. Connecting them with agencies that can provide relocation assistance, housing or other support services has proven to be a successful approach," while also noting no work is yet scheduled. The summary thus highlights the cleanup goals, current status, and collaborative relocation strategy.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a state agency's plan to clean up a homeless encampment, involving safety concerns, law enforcement coordination, and public‑property management, which aligns most closely with Public Safety.

title: 'End of Watch'
author: TAMARA FORTE Special to the Bay Times Record Observer
content: The Fallen Heroes Memorial, hosted by the Fraternal Order of Police Lodge 108, was held this year at Centreville United Methodist Church to honor those lost on February 13, the anniversary of the 2001 deaths of Michael Nickerson and Jason Schwenz. Sheriff Gary Hoffman led a moment of silence and the Pledge of Allegiance, while Pastor Rev. Karen Handy welcomed attendees and spoke of the community’s gratitude. Sue Nickerson explained that “The FOP from QAC started (this event) and they will always have it on February 13, the night that Michael (Nickerson) and Jason (Schwenz, Queen Anne’s County deputy) were killed. But, it's to honor all emergency people who have passed away in the line of duty from Queen Anne’s County.” The names of the fallen were read, including “Buck” Clough of the Sudlersville Volunteer Fire Company and “Dougie” Thomas of the Kent Island Volunteer Fire Department, among others. A presentation of colors, speeches by State’s Attorney Lance Richardson, and bagpipes playing “Amazing Grace” underscored the solemn tribute. The memorial closed with a prayer from Pastor Handy, asking for peace for the families and recognition of the courage of those who served.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a memorial ceremony honoring fallen police, fire, and EMS personnel, which is directly related to public safety and first‑responder activities.

people: Jason Schwenz, Queen Anne’s County deputy, victim
"Dougie" Thomas, Kent Island Volunteer Fire Department

title: Sex offender arrested at Federalsburg school
content: A 26‑year‑old registered sex offender from Easton, Maryland, was arrested on Friday, Oct. 6, for violating the state registry by being on Colonel Richardson High School property while attending a football game.  Roberto Ivan Zaldivar, Jr., is a Tier I offender with a 15‑year Maryland registry and is prohibited from entering any primary or secondary education facility.  He was taken into custody immediately and is held without bond at the Caroline County Detention Center.  At a court hearing on Tuesday, District Judge Joseph Riley set his bail at $10,000.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal arrest for violating sex offender registry rules on school property, which is primarily a public safety issue.

title: Bay Bridge to hold traffic temporarily today
author: Staff Writer
content: The Maryland Transportation Authority (MDTA) will temporarily close the Bay Bridge for 15–30 minutes between 11 a.m. and noon to allow the M/V Dali to pass beneath it en route to Norfolk, with four tugs escorting the vessel for anchoring support. The closure is an abundance of caution, as the ship had recently been involved in the collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore, and authorities want to avoid motorists stopping to look at it. The Queen Anne’s County Office of the Sheriff reports that no traffic congestion is expected on the east side of the bridge. Travelers are advised to use 1‑877‑BAYSPAN (229‑7726) or follow @TheMDTA on X/Twitter for real‑time updates.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a temporary traffic hold on the Bay Bridge for safety reasons, involving the Maryland Transportation Authority, Coast Guard, and sheriff's office, making public safety the most relevant category.

title: Cambridge man charged with kidnap and murder of woman
author: Maggie Trovato
content: Kenneth Stefan Bradley, 40, of Cambridge was indicted March 29 and charged with “murder, assault, kidnapping, false imprisonment and reckless endangerment for the kidnapping and murder of 31-year-old Tiyavauna Britt,” Maryland State Police said. Britt disappeared Feb. 19; her body has not been found. She was last seen in Delaware at work on Feb. 7, and her unlocked car with her phone and wallet inside was later found in an Easton Dollar Tree lot. Charging documents state Britt’s mother told police she had attempted to contact her daughter several times between Jan. 31 and Feb. 13, but had not been able to reach her, and that the mother “believed her daughter was with her ex-boyfriend, identified as Bradley,” fearing for her safety because of “previous domestic violence history between the two.” Bradley is held without bail at Dorchester County Detention Center; anyone with information on Britt’s whereabouts is asked to contact Maryland State Police Sergeant Scott Sears at 443-783-7230.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal investigation, charges, and police actions related to kidnapping and murder, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

people: Kenneth Stefan Bradley, 40, of Cambridge, suspect
Scott Sears, Maryland State Police Sergeant

title: Mid-Shore preps for National Night Out Aug. 5
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content: St. Michaels Police Chief Jeffery Oswald invites residents to “enjoy a hamburger with the fire department, see new law-enforcement equipment, and reconnect with old friends. All of our local partners will be in attendance as we recognize those in the community who have donated their time and care towards a safer St. Michaels.” The Aug. 5 gathering at Bay Hundred Pool, 6-9 p.m., is one of several Mid-Shore National Night Out events designed to strengthen police-community bonds.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on National Night Out events that promote police-community partnerships and neighborhood safety, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic, with a secondary relevance to Local Government due to municipal involvement.

people: Chief Jeffery Oswald, St. Michaels Police Department

title: Electrical fire closes QA high school for a day
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content: An electrical fire that began around 7:13 p.m. on Sept. 9 in a Queen Anne’s County High School special-education room was traced by the Office of the Maryland State Fire Marshal to “an unspecified electrical event of a power surge protector,” causing an estimated $30,000 in damage. Sprinklers held the blaze to the point of origin, leaving water in a hallway, classroom, office and conference room, and the school was closed Wednesday for cleanup before reopening Sept. 11. Interim Superintendent Matthew Kibler thanked responders and staff, while the district posted, “We are thankful that there were no injuries, and our fire suppression system worked appropriately.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on an electrical fire at a high school, focusing on fire response, safety measures, and damage assessment, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

organizations: Office of the Maryland State Fire Marshal

title: Cambridge theater has another incident of smoke in theater
content: For the second time in two weeks, “Fire crews responded Wednesday to the movie theater in Cambridge for the report of smoke.” Both the Aug. 9 incident and the July 29 incident “were determined to be a malfunction in an air handler on the roof of the Cambridge Premier Cinema located on the 2700 block of Dorchester Square Mall.” Multiple fire and emergency crews responded each time.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports fire crews responding to smoke incidents at a cinema, which is a matter of emergency response and public safety rather than sports, education, or other categories.

title: Federalsburg police chief resigns; sheriff's office takes over leadership
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content: At the July 7 town meeting, Mayor Kim Abner said, “The mayor and council would like to announce the resignation of Chief Gasser from the Federalsburg Police Department effective June 25,” and added that the Caroline County Sheriff’s Office will temporarily lead the department. Sheriff Donald Baker told the Star Democrat, “I was contacted by the mayor and council and asked to take over day-to-day operations and management oversight of the department,” and “I agree to do that on an interim basis for 30 to 60 days until the mayor and council decide what they are going to do moving forward and what that looks like for the Federalsburg Police Department.” Baker emphasized that all options are under review, stating, “I believe that everything is on the table to include signing an MOU somewhat like Ridgley’s, directly with the sheriff’s office of the county,” and “Again, everything is on the table. and we are really early in this stage, but we absolutely could absorb any officers that were left.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the resignation of a town police chief and the sheriff's office assuming interim leadership, which directly pertains to public safety matters.

people: Sheriff Donald Baker, Caroline County Sheriff's Office

title: Fire causes $1 million in damage to pizzeria
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content: An investigation is continuing after a blaze caused an estimated one million dollars in damage to a longtime pizzeria near Elkton, forcing the business to close indefinitely, according to the Maryland Office of the State Fire Marshal. A neighboring employee called 911 at 9:57 p.m. on Tuesday, after discovering the fire at Mario's Pizza in the unit block of Beauchamp Road in the Cherry Hill area, a few miles north of Elkton. Approximately 75 firefighters battled the blaze for about 20 minutes before bringing it under control, fire officials reported. The fire caused an estimated $600,000 in structural damage to the pizzeria part of the building, which was equipped with smoke detectors, and it destroyed approximately $400,000 in property inside the shop, according to an MOSFM spokesperson, who further reported that no one was injured.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a fire incident, emergency response, and investigation by the State Fire Marshal, which aligns primarily with public safety concerns.

organizations: Maryland Office of the State Fire Marshal

title: Trams takes helm as Greensboro police chief
author: Connie Connolly
content: Newly sworn Greensboro Police Chief Lenox Trams, a 25-year law-enforcement veteran, says, “We want the best officers who can do the job that the town deserves,” as he plans to add three officers to the department. Colleagues praise his enduring compassion, with Sgt. Al Orrison noting, “When you get to that 15-, 20-year mark, you become very cynical, and it’s hard to have compassion all the time. But Lenox Trams always has compassion for everyone. He treats everybody fairly, and he’s just an incredible human being,” adding that Trams “took me under his wing. My kids actually call him Uncle Lenox. I love this man.” Sgt. David Trevino adds that Trams “never stops giving to people,” and concludes, “The town of Greensboro is very fortunate.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on the swearing‑in of a new police chief, a matter directly related to law enforcement and community safety, making Public Safety the most fitting category, with Local Government as a close secondary fit.

people: Sgt. Al Orrison, Greensboro Police Department
Sgt. David Trevino, Greensboro Police Department

title: Local K-9 units work to overcome retirements from cannabis law
author: Konner Metz
content: Easton and other Maryland departments are in a “complete rebuild” after 2023’s cannabis law forced marijuana-trained dogs into retirement—“This odor of marijuana was enough before 2023 to give us probable cause to search. Now that’s out,” Lt. Tim Larrimore said, adding, “So now you need the ability to smell something that the human nose isn’t necessarily good at detecting. It’s the dog that gets you there.” Replacing them with $14,000 untrained pups like Knox—who’s “very driven to work” because “That means the world to her”—most agencies “were able to replenish the dogs,” Kent’s Sgt. Scott Lockerman noted, though Sheriff Joe Gamble admitted, “I really didn’t want to go down the road because I didn’t want to be challenged in the courtroom.” While Dorchester’s Sheriff James Phillips said the need “was on the horizon” and funding hasn’t “hit us yet” because “These dogs are just retired last year. They’re young, they’re healthy,” officers agree K-9s repay their cost “10 times over because of the relationships that we build with the kids and the people,” and, as Phillips concluded, “an agency…doesn’t have the K-9 ability… I don’t think they’re a full police agency.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on police K‑9 units, their operational challenges, funding, and community impact, which are core aspects of public safety rather than broader government or economic topics.

people: Sgt. Scott Lockerman, Kent County Sheriff's Office

title: Three arrested in connection with death of Centreville teen
author: Staff Writer
content: Three men—Kamryn Andrews, 19, James Lawson, 20, and Travis Lissau, 27—have been arrested and indicted on multiple charges including manslaughter and attempted murder for the June 2025 shooting death of 19-year-old Christopher Parsley at a Centreville bonfire. After a four-month investigation involving federal, state and local agencies, grand-jury indictments led to the trio being held without bond. Sheriff Gary Hofmann said, “This has been an incredibly difficult time for Chris' family and for our entire community. The effects of this tragedy have been deeply felt, and our thoughts remain with those who continue to grieve. This investigation reflects the strength of collaboration between our community and our law enforcement partners.” Detectives continue to solicit tips as the case remains open.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a homicide, arrests, and law‑enforcement investigation, which are core subjects of public safety reporting.

title: Easton man charged with eight counts of child porn possession
author: Maggie Trovato
content: Travis Schwaninger, 42, of Easton was arrested on eight counts of possession of child pornography after the Talbot County Sheriff’s Office Criminal Investigations Division took over the case. “The Easton Police Department Criminal Investigations Unit received several tips in April about Schwaninger from the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children,” and passed the investigation to the Sheriff’s Office when it learned Schwaninger lived outside city limits. On June 11 detectives executed a search warrant at his home, “found additional evidence from Schwaninger’s electronic devices,” arrested him on site, and later released him on a $20,000 unsecured bond. Agencies including the Sheriff’s Patrol Division, Drug Task Force, Crisis Response Unit, Easton Police, and Maryland State Police Computer Crimes Unit assisted; anyone with information is asked to contact Cpl. Samuel Faggert at 410-822-1020 or sfaggert@talbotcountymd.gov.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal investigation and arrest for child pornography, which falls under public safety concerns rather than sports, education, or other categories.
