title: Federalsburg workshops agreement with Caroline County Sheriff's Office
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content: Federalsburg’s Town Council is proceeding with a one-year Memorandum of Understanding that will assign four Caroline County Sheriff’s Office officers—including former Sgt. Brian McNeill—to police the town and save an estimated $280,000 toward its $5 million debt. "We felt as we wanted to give this MOU situation a try for a year, and throughout that year we want to have quarterly meetings with the public," Council Member Brandy James said, underscoring the trial nature of the pact. Under the draft, Federalsburg supplies police vehicles and covers gas, maintenance and $15,000 for uniforms, while the Sheriff’s Office handles crime-related press releases and the town covers municipal announcements.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a town's agreement with the sheriff's office to provide policing services, which is primarily a public safety issue, though it also involves local government budgeting and decision‑making.

people: Brian McNeill, former Sgt., Caroline County Sheriff's Office
Brandy James, Council Member, Federalsburg Town Council

title: Cambridge, Queen Anne's County receive MDOT grants
content: Gov. Wes Moore declared, “In order to create the transportation system that Marylanders deserve, we must work with our citizens, our local officials and our Congressional delegation with unity and focus to deliver safe, equitable access across the state for everyone, whether they drive, ride, or walk,” adding, “These grants help us achieve that goal and help fulfill our mission to lift every community.” Maryland Transportation Secretary Paul Wiedefeld echoed that “The Maryland Department of Transportation is proud to have worked closely with our federal delegation to support our local partners' efforts to receive more than $28 million in funding to boost safety for those who bike, walk and drive on our roads,” and stressed, “The Maryland Department of Transportation looks forward to working with local leaders throughout the state to put this money to use to reduce roadway fatalities and ensure our streets are safer for all Marylanders.” Local leaders including Brentwood Mayor Rocio Treminio-Lopez—“As a historically disadvantaged community, we're grateful for this federal investment… While a small town, we have urban issues that need collaborative approaches to solve”—Baltimore County Executive Johnny Olszewski, Queen Anne’s Commissioner Jim Moran and Cambridge Mayor Stephen Rideout—who noted, “We have a number of streets and intersections that are really quite dangerous, especially to pedestrians”—praised the grants for enabling data-driven plans and infrastructure fixes that prioritize safety across Maryland.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on MDOT grants aimed at reducing traffic fatalities and improving road safety (Vision Zero), which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic, though it also involves local government entities receiving the funds.

title: Train and tractor-trailer collide in Hurlock accident
author: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com
content: A tractor-trailer carrying corn tried to cross the tracks in Hurlock and was struck by an oncoming train, closing Nealson and Broad Streets for hours. Leon Guin, a jockey driver at nearby Amick Farms, said, "Our security guards heard the accident, and two of our outside drivers saw and heard it also. They were bringing the chickens in at that time." No injuries were reported; police and the railroad continue to investigate.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a train‑tractor‑trailer collision, police investigation, road closures, and safety concerns, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

people: Leon Guin, jockey driver at Amick Farms

title: Church outside Trappe struck by lightning; storms cause other minor damages
author: Konner Metz
content: The Faith Chapel United Methodist Church outside Trappe caught fire after a lightning strike Tuesday night, causing $25,000 in damage to the 1880s building. "I was there last night," said Rev. Gary Moore, adding, "Assessing the building will be a difficult decision as we move into the future," though he praised the response crews: "It's what makes living in Talbot County a joy." Across Talbot County, Emergency Services Director Brian LeCates reported, "We had a total of 24 incidents that were storm-related. Most of them are trees down with wires and then just flooding on streets down in Oxford and here in Easton." Easton Utilities CEO John Horner noted, "Every upgrade we make strengthens our system, reduces outages, and ensures we're prepared to meet growing demands," while LeCates urged residents to "Prepare your homes for loose objects that will be blowing around. Secure loose objects."

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on storm‑related incidents, a lightning‑induced fire, emergency response actions, and safety advisories, which align most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Minor injured in Federalsburg vehicle fire
author: Staff Writer
content: A minor sustained non-life-threatening injuries in a Federalsburg vehicle fire reported shortly after 6:40 p.m. Monday, the Office of the State Fire Marshal said. Twenty-four firefighters needed about 20 minutes to extinguish the blaze that consumed a 2002 Ford Explorer. The injured minor was taken to Johns Hopkins Burn Center for treatment of burns to his arms. "The fire does not appear suspicious in nature," the release said, "but the exact cause remains under investigation."

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a vehicle fire, emergency response, and injuries, which are core aspects of public safety reporting.

organizations: Office of the State Fire Marshal

title: Changes ripple through Caroline County law enforcement
author: Staff Writer
content: In Ridgely, town employees and officials have filed a motion to dismiss a federal lawsuit brought by the town's former police chief and officers. The plaintiffs argue the town violated their due process rights when the entire department was laid off last year, while the town maintains it was acting according to its charter and applicable laws. Meanwhile, in Greensboro, the police department has tripled in size this year. Police Chief Lenox Trams, who in January was the department's sole officer, welcomed a third officer this month who joins the department from the now-defunct Federalsburg Police Department.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses recent changes in law enforcement agencies, lawsuits, and staffing within county police departments, which directly relates to public safety issues.

people: Lenox Trams, Police Chief, Greensboro Police Department

title: Preston man pleads guilty to attempted murder - CRIME
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content: Mark William Thompkins, 25, of Preston pleaded guilty Monday to attempted second-degree murder for the February 2022 stabbing of a 25-year-old woman near Holly Park Drive and Gilpin Point Road. Caroline County State's Attorney Sloane Franklin said trash collectors saw Thompkins "striking the woman with his fists, then brandished a knife to stab her neck," before he "cradled her while holding the knife to his own throat" and threatened a would-be rescuer. After a 15-minute pursuit and non-lethal force, "a state trooper was able to knock the knife out of Thompkins' hand to detain him," and both were flown to Shock Trauma. Found incompetent in April 2022, Thompkins was re-evaluated competent this August; Franklin will recommend "a 30-year sentence with all but 15 years of active incarceration suspended," though the plea is non-binding and sentencing is set for Feb. 1, 2024.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a local criminal case involving attempted murder, court proceedings, and law enforcement response, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

people: Sloane Franklin, Caroline County State's Attorney

title: Chestertown pediatrician closes practice amid allegations of abuse
author: HANNAH COMBS hcombs@chespub.com
content: The Maryland State Board of Physicians summarily suspended Dr. Julio Ramirez’s license after finding he sexually assaulted employees and patients, concluding “the public health, safety or welfare imperatively required emergency action in this case.” Attorneys Michael Belsky and Catherine Dickinson, representing a mother who says Ramirez groped her while treating her child, state: “As alleged in the Complaint, Dr. Ramirez was a serial abuser of women. Our office is actively investigating these instances of abuse, especially against mothers who were assaulted while the doctor was treating their children. It goes without saying that this behavior is not acceptable, and we intend to hold the doctor accountable for his actions. We encourage anyone with information on these allegations to reach out to us.” Ramirez, who had opened a Centreville office in 2004 to “better serve the Queen Anne’s and neighboring communities,” permanently surrendered his license and closed his practice, announcing: “It is with a heavy heart that I announce my office has closed permanently… I would like to thank you for your time and the trust you have given me during our many years of operation in Chestertown.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports alleged sexual assault by a pediatrician and a related civil case, which is primarily a crime and public safety issue, though it also involves a health professional.

title: Cambridge man charged with armed carjacking, robbery
content: Kevin McClain, 53, was arrested Oct. 27 in the 700 block of Race Street on 36 charges, including armed carjacking, armed robbery, assault, use of a firearm, reckless endangerment and theft. Police said the charges stem from an Oct. 3 incident where officers responded to the 400 block of Caribbean Avenue around 1:40 a.m. regarding an armed robbery. According to police, the victim reported that after leaving their residence with a friend, another male subject came from the side of the residence, approaching the victim and knocking them to the ground. Police said the victim reported that the teen pulled out a handgun pointing and threatening to shoot them as he went through the victim's pockets, taking their wallet and vehicle keys. An investigation determined the suspect with the gun was a 17-year-old boy from Cambridge who was arrested and charged as an adult, while McClain was identified as the "friend" of the victim. After being processed by CPD and having an initial appearance before a court commissioner, McClain was transported to the Dorchester County Department of Corrections on no bond.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on an armed carjacking, robbery, and subsequent police arrest, which falls squarely under public safety concerns rather than other categories.

title: A 'crisis' on the shore — animal intake on the rise
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content: “I am the president of Professional Animal Workers of Maryland, the state association of shelters and animal control agencies, and we are seeing crisis level intake in our larger municipalities,” said Talbot Humane’s Patty Crankshaw-Quimby, noting 35 % more dogs and 25 % more cats than last year. Caroline director Karen Culotta, whose shelter is at 95 % capacity, attributes the surge to economics: “For some people, with the cost of vet care going up, with the cost of everything going up, or, since the pandemic, sometimes (people) can't afford to feed their animals or can't afford to get vaccinations... It's very challenging for everybody here.” Both leaders stress that “This is why the foster, spay/neuter and intervention programs are so very important,” with Culotta calling the region-wide spike “odd” and declaring, “It's definitely a crisis here on the Eastern Shore.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on animal shelters and animal control agencies dealing with a surge in intake, which falls under public safety functions, with secondary relevance to local government operations and economic factors.

people: Patty Crankshaw-Quimby, president of Professional Animal Workers of Maryland

title: The Star Democrat's top 10 online stories this week
author: STAFF REPORT
content: The Star Democrat’s most-read story of the week covers the arrest of a tractor-trailer driver charged with assault after allegedly hitting a car three times at an Easton red light. Other high-interest pieces include the death of a Dorchester County K-9 left in a hot car, mixed state test scores for Mid-Shore districts, and the Easton council’s reconsideration of food-truck rules. Also drawing attention were the fatal June crash that led to charges against 18-year-old Ellis Mitcham Newcomb and the remembrance of former Police Chief R. Edward “Eddy” Blessing for his lifelong dedication to family, law enforcement and the town.

llm_classification.explanation: The majority of the highlighted stories involve accidents, police actions, and safety incidents, making Public Safety the strongest overall theme despite some local government and education items.

people: R. Edward “Eddy” Blessing, former Easton Police Chief

title: Pride Flags stolen over the weekend
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content: The Chestertown Police Department is investigating the theft of Pride flags and rainbow-themed items from Emmanuel Church on Cross Street, with Cpl. Chris Schwink confirming nine thefts across multiple locations. All suspects are "out of town" males, and while "Nobody's been charged yet, and it's still ongoing," police assured that "appropriate charges will be pending." The department declared on Facebook, "We want everyone to know this type of hate will not be tolerated in Chestertown," urging victims to call 410-778-1800.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a police investigation of thefts targeting Pride flags, focusing on crime and community safety, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

people: Cpl. Chris Schwink, Chestertown Police Department

title: Organizations on the Shore hosts count of people experiencing homelessness
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content: Ashley Kessinger of Mid-Shore Behavioral Health calls the region’s homelessness surge “a crisis,” adding, “Our shelters are completely full, and they stay full all the time. They're all working off of waitlists. They're all trying to find other ways so that people that come to them, don't have to turn them away. But they're just full and we don't have enough.” Yvette Robinson at Neighborhood Service Center says limited resources force groups to lean on one another: “We rely on community partners to try to collaborate so that we can see what's working, what may not be working …we're just trying to get the information out that there are variable resources.” Both stress that stereotypes worsen the problem; Kessinger notes, “People think homelessness looks a certain way and we have seen people from all walks of life and it does not look a certain way,” and urges empathy because “There's a lot of stigma on the shore about homelessness and some people just don't want to see it. If they come across an encampment or something like that, they just want it to go away. …everyone deserves a chance to have a home.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses a point‑in‑time count of homelessness, shelter capacity, and community resources, which are primarily concerns of public safety and social services rather than sports, arts, or other categories.

title: Motorcyclist killed in U.S. 50 Sunday morning crash
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content: Cody Morris was killed on U.S. Route 50 early Sunday after his 2005 Yamaha FZR600 "went off the roadway for unknown reasons and struck the center guardrail," Maryland State Police said. Morris was "thrown into the roadway, where he was subsequently struck by two vehicles traveling westbound," according to police. He "was pronounced dead at the scene by responding emergency medical services," and the incident "is currently under investigation."

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a traffic fatality and police investigation, which falls under public safety rather than sports, health, or other categories.

title: Police, EMS perform active shooter drills at school
author: Konner Metz
content: Local police and emergency medical professionals conducted active-shooter training at The Country Service in Easton on Thursday. "Active shooter situations in elementary and secondary schools caused 328 deaths from 2000 to 2008," according to the National Center for Education Statistics. "That's why before every school year, local first responders have made it a habit to complete active shooter trainings." Caroline County Cpl. Kenny Tull led a drill demonstrating "how critical it is that first responders from different counties to work together cohesively under stress." Officers and EMTs "didn't always make the correct decision every split-second, but they did confer with each other on what steps to take during the next drill, learning how to get better along the way."

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on police and EMS conducting active shooter drills in a school, emphasizing emergency response and safety protocols, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: '25 kids should not take this whole city down' - Cambridge council grapples with youth crime in city
author: Maggie Trovato; mtrovato@chespub.com
content: Lance Cephas warned that “25 kids should not take this whole city down,” insisting that when police just release offenders back into the same environment, “ain’t nothing going to happen … you’ve got to get them and educate them,” and urged the council to stop being “at each other’s throats” and “controlled by 25 kids,” declaring, “We’ve all got to come together” and “find middle ground.” Commissioner Sputty Cephas echoed the compromise theme, noting that “Commissioner Atkiss made a point to say that $100 is a lot of money for a struggling parent,” and added, “My day job is in banking, so I understand that struggle as well,” while resident Theresa Stafford argued, “We need to get serious about fixing the problem of poverty … bringing in industries or businesses that will pay good wages, and of course, supporting getting kids educated because that’s the other key driver that keeps driving up the crime.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on juvenile crime, curfew ordinances, and police involvement, which are core public safety issues, though it also involves city council actions and education aspects.

title: Firefighters handle major town house blaze in St. Michaels
author: Konner Metz
content: Assistant Chief Phil Jones reported that two of the six town house units will be "displaced for some time" after Saturday’s St. Michaels blaze, which drew more than 70 firefighters from four counties. Jones noted that sweltering weather hampered crews, saying, "With the heat, it makes it twice as hard for us," and required constant hydration and medical checks. Despite the estimated $1 million loss, no injuries occurred, and Jones praised the volunteer responders, adding, "We all work together to complete everything."

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a fire incident and the response by fire departments, which falls squarely under public safety rather than sports, education, or other categories.

title: UPDATED: Easton High School evacuating due to bomb threat
author: STAFF REPORT
content: Easton High School was placed on lockdown Monday afternoon after officials announced, "Easton High has received a Bomb threat. At this time the school is on lockdown," and students and staff were evacuated to the stadium while deputies responded. The Talbot County Sheriff’s Office stated, "This is an ongoing investigation and Deputies will be on scene for several hours," and urged the public, "Please avoid the area and obey police detours. We will be sure to release additional information as soon as it becomes available."

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a bomb threat and evacuation at a high school, focusing on police response and safety measures, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Family fights Dunkirk cemetery's plan to move plot
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content: When Laura Dodgson learned Southern Memorial Gardens wants to exhume and relocate her parents and siblings, she replied, “I don’t want them moved,” but cemetery attorney Kevin Vitelli insists, “It happens at every cemetery. Mistakes were made in 1989. We're just trying to make it right,” adding, “There were some mistakes made by prior owners. We have to correct those mistakes.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a cemetery's alleged mishandling of burial plots, past fraud investigations, and potential negligence, which aligns most closely with public safety concerns about proper handling of remains and consumer protection.

title: Easton man gets five years for narcotics charges
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content: Jaurice K. Henry, 27, was sentenced Nov. 22 to “two 15-year sentences and suspending all but five years of each in a binding agreement,” with the five-year terms to run concurrently, followed by three years of supervised probation. The charges arose after Easton Police responded to the Econo Lodge on Dec. 5, 2022, for an overdose victim, and “after several months, Henry and Iyana Wilson, 27, were identified as the individuals who sold a cocaine and fentanyl mix to the victim, police said.” Wilson still faces two pending cases: one for which she “entered an Alford plea to possession with intent to distribute narcotics” and is set for sentencing Dec. 15, and a second charging her with manufacturing narcotics, conspiring with Henry, and related offenses, scheduled for a Dec. 1 status conference.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal sentencing for narcotics possession and distribution, involving police investigation and court proceedings, which aligns with public safety matters.

title: Chester man charged in murder of father
author: Staff Writer
content: Drew Bernard Meyer, 32, of Chester, has been charged with first-degree murder in the May 17 death of his 65-year-old father, Wayne Michael Meyer, after deputies responding to a cardiac-arrest call found the elder man dead under “suspicious circumstances.” Sheriff Gary Hofmann called the slaying “an isolated domestic situation,” adding, “Our thoughts are with the Meyer family during this incredibly difficult time. We are committed to protecting the privacy of the family as they navigate this tragic event. This was an isolated domestic situation, and we appreciate the public's trust in our investigators to bring this case to a swift conclusion. We are grateful that Drew Meyer will now be processed through the criminal justice system, ensuring that justice is served.” Meyer is held without bond pending an Aug. 7 preliminary hearing.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a criminal investigation and arrest for murder, which falls under public safety concerns rather than sports, education, or other categories.

title: Straw bales burn off Route 50 in Trappe
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content: Area fire departments responded around 9 a.m. Thursday to multiple straw bales on fire in the Lakeside at Trappe development's proposed irrigation field at the end of Backtown Road, after a farmer's report. Fire department personnel on scene said "the fire may have been burning for a day before fire personnel responded." The narrow gravel and dirt access road complicated equipment access, and an excavator from Retallack & Sons arrived about 11:30 a.m. "to create a fire break."

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a fire incident involving straw bales and the response of fire departments, which is primarily a public safety issue.

title: Time to remove delivery boxes
author: Staff Writer
content: The editor notes that halting hand delivery of the Star Democrat is “perhaps economically necessary and practical,” but thousands of rusted yellow delivery boxes remain in yards and along roads. Suzanne Hood asks, “how to unearth the boxes without buying tools, hiring someone or hurting ourselves,” and warns “Those boxes do not get prettier with time and will continue to mar our beautiful highways until they are removed.” She wonders, “If we get them out of the ground, can someone collect them and dispose of them in a responsible way? Too rusty and dangerous for service groups or school kids to get service hours?” and urges a solution “for keeping our scenery free of antiquated ugliness, OK?”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the hazard posed by rusted delivery boxes in public spaces and calls for safe removal, which aligns most closely with public safety concerns.

title: Crime in Cambridge 'trending down,' police department says
author: MAGGIE TROVATO mtrovato@chespub.com
content: Cambridge Police Chief Justin Todd says crime is “trending down,” noting drops in reported incidents, ShotSpotter alerts and shots-fired calls, and credits officers who are “patrol with a purpose, be in our high-crime areas,” adding, “A lot of credit goes to our officers that are out doing what we're asking of them to do as an administration.” While acknowledging “We know there's more out there, and we know there's still crime,” Todd insists, “But we're making progress,” yet calls juvenile crime levels “stagnant,” saying, “I think there's a lot of work to do with juvenile reform. We have to put more emphasis on figuring out why these kids are out committing these crimes and getting in touch with families by working through social services and Juvenile Services,” and warns, “When the kids get out of school, that'll be a big factor of just how good we're doing crime-wise.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on crime trends, police department statistics, and safety initiatives, which directly relate to public safety concerns.

title: 2 arrested on gun charges in Days Inn incident
author: Konner Metz
content: Ernest Young Jr. and Katherine Adkins were arrested Aug. 12 after Young allegedly pointed a gun at James Terrell in a Days Inn room, then "Young grabbed Adkins and took her back" inside. A woman upstairs told police Adkins "knocked on her door and handed her a handgun," saying "'Take this 'cause I don't want to get in trouble,'" before officers recovered the weapon. Young faces assault and four gun counts; Adkins is charged with handgun offenses, accessory, and tampering.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on a police response, arrests, and firearm charges, which are matters of public safety rather than sports, education, or other categories.

title: Leaving a timeless mark: Remembering lives lost with roadside memorials
author: MARTY MADDEN mmadden@somdnews.com
content:
Deborah Carrington-Smith’s cross for her 19-year-old daughter Tiffani—killed when “Her car, a 1987 Nissan 300ZX, was broadsided by a Charles County sheriff's officer”—declares “This is who Tiffani was to our family: she was a child full of spunk… and was never stingy with her affection,” while the SHA warns that “Roadside Tribute… must comply with the law… crews keep any intact roadside memorials at the nearest shop.”  
Across the region, Autumn Jenkins’s kin “have a stone that was engraved with a drawing of a dog… We actively attend DUI checkpoints,” Jonna Jones ran a half-marathon for Lauren Pitt because “Her enthusiasm for people made me feel like I could do anything,” Kandia Spain keeps flowers where “Joseph” died “for unknown reasons,” and a small cross for 8-year-old Brysen lies where the children “were found to not be correctly restrained.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on road deaths, memorials, and the safety/legal issues surrounding roadside markers, which best fits the Public Safety category.

title: Bill could improve police awareness of unseen disabilities
author: SOfIA APPOLONIO Capital News Service
content: Lawmakers are weighing Eric’s ID Law, which lets Marylanders add an unseen-disability marker to driver’s licenses because, as bill namesake Eric Grantham said, “Eric's ID Law was created to help save lives for people who cannot use their own voice.” Prince George’s Sheriff John Carr called the resource a “must,” adding, “From a law enforcement perspective, we want you to know that we are here to serve you and we want this bill to pass,” and “Any time that we're able to put a citizen at ease during a traffic stop, that is something that helps us interact and keep our community safe.” The bill would “provide increased training for law enforcement and other public service entities,” complementing existing tools like the MVA “blue card,” all to address Del. Kym Taylor’s warning that “There are no visible signs nor immediate indicators to help first responders understand potential reactions.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a proposed law affecting police interactions with individuals who have invisible disabilities, which is primarily a public safety issue, while also addressing racial concerns.

title: Fire Marshal investigating Greensboro vehicle fire
author: STAFF REPORT
content: The Office of the State Fire Marshal is investigating an intentional vehicle fire that occurred on Kibler Road Friday night, "the second incident in four days at the location." Family members found the passenger compartment of Linda Bennett’s 2011 Kia "ablaze...just before midnight Friday," and Greensboro Volunteer Fire Company firefighters needed "around 20 minutes...to control" it, with no injuries reported and about "$4,000 in damage to the car and its contents." This follows an earlier June 25 blaze in which "an abandoned mobile home had been intentionally set on fire" at the same address, a structure that "had been abandoned for more than 15 years" and also caused no injuries. Anyone with information on either fire should contact the Upper Eastern Regional Office of the Maryland State Fire Marshal at 410-822-7609.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on an investigation by the State Fire Marshal into intentional vehicle and property fires, focusing on safety, fire response, and public alerts, which aligns directly with the Public Safety topic.

title: Easton's new fire chief has plans for equipment, recruitment
author: Konner Metz
content: J.R. Dobson, elected Easton’s new volunteer fire chief in December, grew up in a “everybody knew everybody” firehouse culture and now leads the county’s largest department, observing, “There’s a lot of tradition here. It’s certainly the biggest department in the county... It’s a business. And we’re all here for free, none of us get paid.” Drawing on his day-job command of 35 sheriff’s deputies, Dobson says, “I think that I bring a lot of management skills, leadership skills. Just from my experience there, I think it helps you here,” a view echoed by predecessor Sonny Jones: “I’ve known J.R. the entire time that I’ve been a member of the Easton fire department... J.R. is a first-rate guy. He’s a terrific leader.” With recruitment lagging—“Those are things that we’ve done well in the past, although the last year or so we haven’t gotten as many members as we would like”—Dobson insists, “We got to get people in here. We’ve got to get these trucks out. And I think that the way the town’s growing, if we don’t grow with it, then we’re failing ourselves.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the appointment of a new fire chief, fire department operations, recruitment, and equipment—issues that pertain directly to public safety services.

title: Democratic lawmakers plan to crack down on youth crime in the coming weeks
author: STEPH QUINN Capital News Service
content: Democratic leaders, including Gov. Wes Moore, unveiled plans to route 10- to 13-year-olds accused of auto theft or handgun violations to court, arguing the move will close gaps where “Egos, political agendas and arguments over process have filled the gaps,” said House Speaker Adrienne Jones. Senate President Bill Ferguson added there must be “accountability for adults in the system, who are charged with administering the system.” Youth advocates counter that the “legislation introduced today will see thousands more kids incarcerated every year, particularly Black and brown children, and (exacerbate) the already serious racial disparities in Maryland's juvenile justice system.” Still, House Minority Leader Jason Buckel praised Moore: “For him to be able to step in and say, ‘Hey, I'm a Democrat. I'm from Baltimore City, but I'm going to step up and say too much is too much and this is a reasonable way to deal with this’ — it's incredibly helpful.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses proposed legislation targeting youth crime, juvenile court procedures, and public safety concerns, making Public Safety the most relevant category.

title: Talbot, Queen Anne's counties included on Trump's list of 'sanctuary jurisdictions'
author: Konner Metz
content: Queen Anne’s County blasted the administration’s “sanctuary” tag as “wholly inaccurate,” insisting it has “never adopted or endorsed sanctuary policies … that would shield individuals in violation of federal immigration law,” and vowed, “We have, and will continue to, follow all applicable federal laws and have not taken any deliberate actions to obstruct their enforcement,” while adding, “We welcome further information and guidance from the federal government so we can address any pertinent issues.” Talbot officials echoed the denial, with Sheriff Joe Gamble saying, “They haven’t asked us to do anything,” and Queen Anne’s Sheriff Gary Hofmann calling the claim “continued misinformation that’s been perpetuated now,” noting his “zero tolerance” stance “hasn’t changed on how we deal with criminals.” The counties’ surprise inclusion on DHS’s roster of places “defying federal immigration law,” based on criteria like “compliance with federal law enforcement, information restrictions, and legal protections for illegal aliens,” puts grants at risk of “suspension or termination, as appropriate,” prompting Gamble to say, “We hope that we can reapply and renew that grant.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on immigration enforcement, sanctuary designations, and potential impacts on law‑enforcement grants, which are core public safety issues, while also involving county officials, making Public Safety the strongest match.

title: Longtime fire department volunteer remembered in fishing tournament
author: Contributed
content: The third Big Al’s Gone Fishin’ Tournament, held June 3 at Doc’s Sunset Grille, raised over $6,500 for the Oxford Volunteer Fire Company in honor of lifetime member Alvin “Big Al” Ledford. Mark Ledford, Alvin’s son and event organizer, thanked key supporters: “In particular, I'd like to acknowledge Doc's Sunset Grille, Campbell's Boat Yard, and Roto-Rooter of Delmarva.” Proceeds will outfit the fire boat with new radios, lights and graphics and replace worn equipment, said Oxford Fire Co. president Tim Kearns. Doc’s owner Chooch Oristian praised the turnout—“It was busy and a great crowd this year, and we look forward to being part of the Tournament next time”—capturing the spirit of the community gathering.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a volunteer fire department, honoring a longtime firefighter and raising funds for fire equipment, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Man dies in crash as he avoided tree
content: A Federalsburg man, Steven Alan Keene Jr., was killed in a single-car crash on Smithville Road at 6:30 a.m. Wednesday, according to police. Deputies found his 2004 Chevrolet Monte Carlo had “sustained heavy front-end damage after leaving the road in an attempt to avoid a fallen tree.” Police said “speed, wet road conditions and lack of seatbelt use are factors in the crash.” The investigation is ongoing with help from the Maryland State Police Accident Reconstruction Unit; anyone with information should contact the Caroline County Sheriff’s Office at 410-479-2515.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a fatal traffic accident and mentions police investigation, which aligns most closely with the Public Safety topic.

title: Fire, exacerbated by hoarding, rips through house killing two
author: Matt Wynn mwynn@somdnews.com
content: A fire claimed the lives of two Charles County men on Thursday morning. Firefighters responded at 6:15 a.m. to Brunswick Road in Faulkner, where “smoke [was] pouring from the structure.” Robert Bowling, 62, and Kim Dickens, 70, were found “deceased in the remains of the home,” while a first-floor tenant escaped uninjured. The Charles County Volunteer Fire and Emergency Medical Services Facebook page reported “there were severe hoarder conditions at the site, evidenced by photographs of items littered throughout the property.” Damage is estimated at $175,000 to the structure and $75,000 in contents; smoke alarms were present but “it is unknown if they were working.” An investigation is ongoing.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports a residential fire, emergency response, and fatalities, which are core aspects of public safety reporting.

title: Two teens charged in connection to burglaries in Easton
author: Maggie Trovato
content: Two 17-year-olds have been referred to the Maryland Department of Juvenile Services and charged in connection to burglaries in Easton. According to a news release from the Easton Police Department, detectives connected a teen from Randallstown to three burglaries and a teen from Oxon Hill to one of those burglaries. Police said officers responded Oct. 28 to a report of a burglary at Finest Vape and Smoke Shop on Marlboro Avenue around 4:25 a.m. The same day, about an hour later, police said patrolling officers noticed the front glass door of Smoke Nation on Ocean Gateway was broken. On Dec. 16 around 3:15 a.m., police said officers were again dispatched to Finest Vape and Smoke Shop in reference to a burglary. On Friday, the two teens were referred to the Department of Juvenile Services and charged.

llm_classification.explanation: The article reports on teenage suspects, police investigations, and charges for burglaries, which falls squarely under public safety and crime reporting.

title: Fire to Federalsburg residence causes $95,000 in damages

content: Around 5:30 a.m. Saturday, firefighters responded to West Central Avenue for a blaze at a one-story structure, according to the Office of the State Fire Marshal. "No injuries were reported." The Federalsburg Volunteer Fire Company led the response, with "around 25 firefighters controlled the blaze in 25 minutes, the fire marshal said." Investigators estimate damages at $95,000 and say "the fire originated in a storage room," though "no cause has been determined." Anyone with information is asked to contact the Upper Eastern Regional Office of the Maryland State Fire Marshal at 410-819-3500.

title: Workshop encourages becoming an informed weather spotter
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content: Warning Coordinator Meteorologist Sarah Johnson urged Kent County residents to join SKYWARN, stressing that “The main mission of the spotter is to be aware of the rapidly changing conditions of the weather,” and noting people tune in for a “tornado warning” but ignore a “severe thunderstorm warning.” “That’s a mistake to think one’s worse than the other,” she said, pointing out that “When we look at the fatalities, 75% in the United States are due to water in some way; 50% of those are those are due to storm surge; 25% freshwater heavy rain flooding. Keep that in mind. Don’t think, ‘Oh, it’s just a tropical storm.’ No, you still need to pay attention and see what the hazards are.” “That’s why we need you all,” Johnson added, promising recruits that “There can be no finer reward than to know that your efforts have given your family and neighbors the precious gift of time—minutes that can help save lives,” while joking that the upcoming movie “Twisters” will surely stir fresh questions.

llm_classification.explanation: The article describes a workshop that trains volunteers to report severe weather, emphasizing preparedness and life‑saving actions, which aligns most closely with public safety rather than purely educational or governmental topics.

title: Youth not facing consequences for breaking laws
author: Thomas R. Hurley; Fraternal Order Of Police
content: Thomas R. Hurley of the Fraternal Order of Police warns that Maryland’s new juvenile-justice rules mean a youth who “not be charged with any crime is under 10 years old” and that those under 13 can only be charged for violent crimes, leaving theft, burglary, drug and gun offenses unpunishable. He says officers must release even kids caught with loaded handguns or stolen cars, cannot interrogate anyone under 18 without a lawyer, and can only offer a social-services referral—so gangs are already recruiting children as “career criminals.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses recent changes to juvenile criminal law and their impact on policing and community safety, making public safety the most relevant category.

title: Cambridge police ready for National Night Out
author: Lily Tierney
content:
Cambridge Police Sgt. Antione Patton bought 100 pumpkins Monday for the department’s National Night Out, moved from August to Oct. 7, 5-7 p.m. at Great Marsh Park, to avoid heat and add pumpkin decorating, a hayride, TV giveaways and CPD’s first pie-eating contest.  
"Most of the time, the only time the community and the children get opportunities to engage with law enforcement is at a call, and normally that is when people are at their worst," Patton said. "And we want people that are having a good time, to actually have time to talk to police officers about other things than problems and issues."

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on a police department organizing a community event (National Night Out) to foster positive interaction between law enforcement and residents, which directly relates to public safety initiatives.

title: Anton Black's family settles with state medical examiner
author: Natalie Jones; njones@chespub.com
content: The $235,000 settlement in the Anton Black case forces Maryland’s Office of the Chief Medical Examiner to adopt new policies that ensure transparency, impartiality, and “independence from improper law enforcement influence.” Richard Potter of the Coalition for Justice for Anton Black said, “I hope that with this settlement agencies will begin to recognize their own wrongdoings, catch them and change them before they cause harm,” adding that “What is needed is a sense of shared ownership that can only come through trust and mutual accountability, with police confronting their own biases about mental illness, committing to de-escalation, and truly serving a diverse community.” ACLU senior staff attorney Sonia Kumar said, “We can’t prevent such deaths if we aren’t honest about what caused them, and this settlement is a crucial step towards that goal in future cases,” and warned, “We hope this settlement will make a real, positive impact, but it is truly just the beginning of the reckoning needed to address decades of misrepresentations so we can bring justice to families still waiting for the government to tell the truth.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a police restraint death, settlement, and reforms to police and medical examiner practices, which are core issues of public safety. Race & Diversity is also relevant due to the focus on a Black victim and systemic bias, while Local Government is involved through the Board of Public Works approval.

title: Caroline County leaning towards not going forward with Regional Detention Center
author: AHMAD GARNETT agarnett@chespub.com
content: Caroline County is poised to withdraw from the planned 388-bed regional detention center at 700 Flat Iron Square Road near Church Hill after concluding it offers no financial benefit. “Unfortunately, because of their schedule and their pay scale, I don’t think Caroline County is going to save any money by entering into the agreement,” Commissioners President Travis Breeding said. “If we’re not going to save any money, why relinquish the autonomy that we have right now to operate as our own facility and better suit the needs of the Caroline County as opposed to a three-county organization,” he added. Breeding said, adding the county spent a lot of time studying the proposal. The draft agreement had placed most authority with Queen Anne’s County, including veto power over the warden and the right to expel partner counties with two-year notice.

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on county officials debating participation in a regional detention center, a facility directly related to public safety and corrections, making Public Safety the most fitting category.

title: The Star Democrat's top 10 online stories this week
author: STAFF REPORT
content:
The most-viewed public safety stories on The Star Democrat’s website include three Cambridge incidents: “A Cambridge police officer fatally shot a man who the police Department said was armed with a knife and threatening advances toward officers,” “The Maryland Office of Attorney General identified an armed man killed by a Cambridge police officer last week, as well as the officer involved in the shooting,” and “Cambridge police arrested a 15-year-old after the teen allegedly shot his stepfather in the face Friday, according to a police news release.”  
In Easton, “The stands were cleared part way through the third quarter of Easton High School's football game against Colonel Richardson High School last week” after reports of a handgun.  
Additionally, “A woman is being held at the Talbot County Detention Center after being accused of spray-painting graffiti around town, including at Sts. Peter and Paul Elementary School.”

title: Videos of Easton High School assault circulate online
author: Veronica Fernandez-Alvarado
content: Videos of a Tuesday assault at Easton High School show two students attacking a student in a red hoodie and a staff member who tried to shield him, leaving one student with non-life-threatening injuries. The Talbot County Sheriff’s Office said two students have been arrested and the incident remains under investigation. Talbot County Public Schools communications director Debbie Gardner stated: “The safety of our students and staff is always our top priority. We are grateful for our partnership with the Talbot County Sheriff's Office and the presence of School Resource Officers in our schools,” adding, “Deputy Horseman, along with several other Sheriff's deputies and members of the Easton High staff responded quickly to contain the incident. The students involved will face appropriate disciplinary action, and we are continuously evaluating safety measures to prevent or mitigate incidents of this nature.”

title: Old mill to be demolished
author: ANDREA GRABENSTEIN agrabenstein@chespub.com
content: The Centreville Town Council voted Aug. 7 to demolish the deteriorating mill at 2647 Centreville Road, giving the owner 10 days to act before the town steps in. Council President Ashley Kaiser called the accompanying new administrative-search-warrant ordinance “a step in the right direction and puts us in line with a lot of towns around us.” With three applicants for two October council seats, longtime member Jim Beauchamp—who has served off and on for a decade—plans to withdraw if both rivals stay in the race, saying simply, “It’s been a good 10 years.”

title: Federalsburg apartment fire displaces 14
author: STAFF REPORT
content: A July 5 fire at the Federalsburg Manor Apartments displaced 14 people, according to a report from the Office of the State Fire Marshal. There were no injuries reported in the fire, which broke out shortly after 7 p.m. and took 30 firefighters about 30 minutes to control. The blaze resulted in an estimated $400,000 in damages. According to the fire marshal's report, the fire was discovered in the bedroom of an apartment by the apartment's occupant, who attempted to extinguish the blaze with a bucket of water but was unsuccessful. The occupant then called 911. The American Red Cross is assisting those who were displaced by the fire.

title: After-school activities canceled, some Wednesday delays in place due to strong storm
author: Natalie Jones
content: A powerful storm has prompted Dorchester County Public Schools to run a half-day Tuesday and a two-hour delay Wednesday, while Queen Anne's County schools dismissed early Tuesday and will open 90 minutes late Wednesday, with after-school activities canceled across both counties. Talbot and Caroline counties also scrapped Tuesday activities and are monitoring conditions for Wednesday. Gov. Wes Moore declared a State of Preparedness, and meteorologist Mike Lee warned, “The main concern is the potential for coastal flooding in Talbot and Queen Anne's counties,” with Dorchester also facing significant flooding. Coastal flood warnings and wind advisories are in effect through Wednesday morning, with gusts up to 60 mph possible and widespread power outages expected.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on storm‑related hazards, flood warnings, and emergency directives, emphasizing safety measures and public alerts, which aligns best with Public Safety.

title: Cambridge man arrested on 30 charges following vehicle pursuit
author: STAFF REPORT
content: Keizye Daijuon Collins, 27, was arrested on 30 charges after fleeing a Cambridge traffic stop and crashing into a house. Police say Collins sped off “at a high rate of speed,” then “swerved” at a patrol car whose officer “had to make evasive maneuvers to avoid being struck.” After striking the Charles Street house, Collins ran but was later identified and arrested on July 8.

title: Fire Marshal investigates abandoned mobile home fire
author: Maggie Trovato
content: The Office of the State Fire Marshal has determined that the preliminary cause of a fire in an abandoned mobile home on Kibler Road was incendiary. According to a news release from the Office of the State Fire Marshal, the fire — which is still under investigation — was discovered by a passerby Tuesday. The fire did not cause any injuries or deaths, and the Office of the State Fire Marshal said the home was vacant and had been abandoned for more than 15 years. The blaze resulted in an estimated loss of $1,000, and it took 12 firefighters 30 minutes to control the one alarm fire.

title: Caroline Police Accountability Board reports progress
author: Connie Connolly
content:
Chairman John Bartlett stressed it is “very important” to note that only six complaints arose from the Sheriff’s 26,000-plus calls, saying “I think that speaks volumes with law enforcement here in Caroline County,” while Administrator Kimberly Raeder outlined the three boards’ roles: the Police Accountability Board “is to receive police complaints, recommend policy changes and identify any trends,” the five-member Administrative Charging Committee’s role “is to look over and review completed complaint investigations and recommend discipline,” and, if charges are filed, they “decide what kind of discipline would be necessary based on the complaint.”  
Of 21 total complaints county-wide, four are pending, two were deemed “not in the purview of the ACC,” and the boards did “not…recommend any changes at this time,” though “A common identified trend, however, has been the lack of activation of body cameras when officers interact with the public…The ACC discovered this trend when reviewing completed complaint investigations which had no body camera footage…The policy protects both the Officer and the Citizen.”  
The county has already provided “financial support of the committee for legal decisions when needed,” and commissioners “agreed to bear the expense of hiring outside legal counsel” whose “Legal Counsel attends each quarterly meeting and provides interpretation of the Maryland Police Accountability Act of 2021 as needed,” while the Board urges the state to keep funding “the required technology, resources, and tools to comply with the law,” and recommends “changing ACC training from all in-person training to online meeting based or pre-recorded online training” because uncompensated training shrinks the volunteer pool; it also proposes limiting Charging Committee cases to “matters of public concern,” i.e., “police misconduct, such as abuse of power, false arrest, police brutality, or criminal activity,” and letting departments handle “Rude and discourteous” behavior internally.

llm_classification.explanation: The article discusses the Caroline County Police Accountability Board, complaints against law enforcement, and oversight policies, which are primarily matters of public safety, though they also involve local government structures.

people: John Bartlett, Chairman, Caroline County Police Accountability Board
Kimberly Raeder, Administrator, Caroline County Police Accountability Board

title: CASA of the Mid-Shore celebrates its volunteers
author: Maggie Trovato
content: At a volunteer-appreciation evening at Avalon Theatre, CASA of the Mid-Shore Executive Director Robin Davenport declared, “The people who bring our mission to life are our CASA volunteers,” adding, “And so we're here tonight because everyone in this room talks the talk and walks the walk. And that is really important to us, but certainly to the future of the kids who we're working with.” New volunteer Larry Neviaser echoed the praise, saying, “They recognize the value of the volunteers, and (that) it really makes the organization,” while keynote speaker Frank Kros reminded the crowd, “It's incredible what we can do when someone genuinely believes in us and provides us the support that we need.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on CASA volunteers who advocate for children at risk and under court protection, which relates to child safety and protection services, fitting the Public Safety category best.

title: Meet the bikers who try – and fail – each year to erode Maryland’s helmet law
author: SAPNA BANSIL Capital News Service
content: For 32 years ABATE’s leather-vested “diehards” have marched on Annapolis, and Bob Spanburgh shrugs, “It’s been 32 years this year to no avail … But we keep introducing it. We have some pretty ardent supporters. We have a lot of people who think we’re nuts, probably,” while the bill named for Gary “Pappy” Boward again seeks choice, not mandates. Sen. Mike McKay, who like Sen. Jill Carter frames it as a civil-liberty issue—“I firmly believe that we as government do better when we educate people, [rather] than legislating something … There are people that would like to have the choice [to not wear a helmet.] And I tend to believe that we should give people the choice but 100% support educating them about it”—credits ABATE with turning Spanburgh, once politically indifferent, into an activist after “the first meeting I went to, the thing they told me [was,] ‘You got to register to vote. It’s very important in this organization,’ … That was actually the first time I ever registered to vote in my life. I was 27 at the time.” Opponents counter that “your decision then ends up costing the entire system a whole lot of money,” yet the bill faces a Senate hearing and, win or lose, Ken Eaton vows, “If I don’t do it, who else is going to do it?”

llm_classification.explanation: The article centers on a legislative effort to change Maryland's mandatory helmet law, a matter directly tied to traffic safety and public health outcomes, making Public Safety the most fitting category.

title: County says new paramedic station in Cordova will reduce wait times for residents
author: Konner Metz
content: Talbot County broke ground Monday on a $2.1 million Cordova paramedic station that officials say will cut ambulance wait times in an area “underserved by that,” LeCates noted. “Council members fully funded the $2.1 million project, which will be the county's sixth paramedic station. It will include space for a 24/7 paramedic and EMT unit. Council President Chuck Callahan said the project comes at an important time as renovations are progressing at the elementary school across the street.” Jimmy Eason, president of the Talbot County Volunteer Fire and Rescue Association, said the station is welcomed “with open arms.” “Unfortunately for us in Cordova, we're facing almost a 100% failure to respond rate,” Eason said. Callahan thanked the Gannon family for donating farmland; LeCates praised Sylvia Gannon, a former council member and Talbot Paramedic Foundation founder.

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on the construction of a new EMS/paramedic station to improve emergency response times, which directly relates to public safety services.

title: Be responsible on the water
author: Staff Writer
content: May 17-23 is National Safe Boating Week, and the Safe Boating Campaign reminds Eastern Shore boaters to “Wear a life jacket. No matter what activity you have planned on the water, always remember to wear a life jacket every time you are on the water.” Capt. Brett M. Sause, a USCG master licensed captain, urges boaters to know state laws, take a safety course, check the vessel and weather, file a float plan, avoid alcohol, guard against carbon monoxide—“install and maintain a working CO detector, never block exhaust outlets, and always dock, beach or anchor at least 20 feet away from the nearest boat that is running a generator or engine”—and carry at least two communication devices that work when wet.

llm_classification.explanation: The article provides safety guidelines for boating, focusing on preventing accidents and injuries, which aligns best with the Public Safety topic.

title: Telling the truth matters
author: Staff Writer
content: The Dorchester County Republican Central Committee recently claimed “protesters were being brought here on buses,” but the article counters, “That is not accurate.” It explains, “While some protesters come from other counties, most are local. They live here in Dorchester, mostly from Cambridge … or nearby places like Worcester and Talbot counties. They are Andy Harris's constituents, just like you.” The piece also notes, “No proof has been shown to support” claims of violence threats, warning, “Sharing information that isn't true creates fear. This can hurt our community.” It concludes, “Telling the truth matters. It protects us all.”

llm_classification.explanation: The article focuses on misinformation about protests and threats of violence, emphasizing community safety, which aligns best with the Public Safety topic. title: Strained blue lines - Police battle mental health challenges along with crime
author: Mike Sunnucks; Apg National Enterprise Editor
content: Departments nationwide are reviving or expanding peer-support and reimbursement programs because, as Sarasota’s Capt. Kenneth Rainey says, “It never got the attention it deserved” and “It’s all about affecting a new culture within an organization that it is OK to say you are not ok.” Those efforts include Wyoming’s Laramie County, where Sheriff Brian Kozak—who noted “Just a few weeks ago, we had a deputy who was stabbed”—reports “We’re looking to expand that,” and Wisconsin’s new fund whose coordinator explained, “The fund was recently established to reimburse local law enforcement personnel for mental health expenses not covered by their health insurance; grants will be paid directly to the Eau Claire County Sheriff's Department… and applied to their requests for reimbursement.” Advocates stress “Nobody knows officers better than their coworkers and fellow employees. We're really trying to eliminate the stigmas associated with mental health saying that its OK to ask for help,” while veteran commanders concede “I am old school, 43 years on the job, so this was difficult for me to learn, but being in a command position changes your perspective when looking out for the welfare of your people,” and push “frequent reminders that seeking help is not a sign of weakness.” The message is delivered amid public hostility—“It’s challenging to put on a police uniform and feel or just assume there is just disdain for you just as a result of your profession”—that many feel unfairly spotlights the “bad actions of a few police officers,” because, as Rainey reminds, “Individuals know in their own hearts that the great majority of police get involved because they want to help people.”

title: County buys mask testing system to keep firefighters safe

content: Talbot County has purchased an OSHA-compliant AeroFit testing system to let any station conduct on-site fit tests for N95s, gas masks and other gear, eliminating outside service costs and boosting safety for all emergency responders. “With the county's support, this system ensures that every responder, whether volunteer, law enforcement, or emergency services staff, can be confident their protective equipment will keep them safe,” said Jimmy Eason, President of the Talbot County Volunteer Fire & Rescue Association. title: Investigation continues after children die in Perryville home
author: Carl Hamilton cahamilton@chespub.com
content: Maryland State Police are investigating the "circumstances surrounding the suspicious deaths" of a 10-year-old boy and his 14-year-old sister, who were found after troopers responded to what police called the "cardiac arrest of two juveniles" at their Cole Street home in Perryville. "The preliminary investigation indicates the sister of the juveniles came home and found both children unconscious inside the home. Investigators determined the two juveniles were brother and sister living in the house with their mother," an MSP spokesperson said, adding that no signs of violence were evident. Autopsies are planned, and "A search warrant was obtained for the house. Crime scene technicians from the Maryland State Police processed the area and a search of the premises was conducted," the spokesperson confirmed.

content:
Prosecutor James Dellmyerr told jurors “Thirteen seconds, in real-time, you are going to see the intentional, premediated killing of Mr. Cimorose,” adding “This is is evidence of first-degree murder. Chris (Cimorore) didn’t’t stand a chance. That gun was on him before he got out of the car,” and argued “You cannot start a fistfight and then shoot someone to death,” asking “Is it reasonable to use deadly force?”

The jury acquitted Snyder of all counts.

content: Jose Garcia Tovar, 22, of Easton, died in a single-car crash on June 15 just south of Severn, Anne Arundel County police said. title: Kent Samaritan Group nears goal to open emergency shelter in December
author: WILL BONTRAGER wbontrager@chespub.com
content: The Samaritan Group of Kent County has raised $12,000 of its $14,000 goal to open the Emergency Winter Shelter in December, a first in the shelter’s 22-year history. Shelter Director Rev. James Diggs urged the community, “Let’s make this month a recruiting month. Help us do it because I think we certainly can. We’re excited to be able to add December and maybe next year, add another month,” emphasizing that 85 % of December volunteer slots—especially Christmas Eve, Christmas, New Year’s Eve and New Year’s—must be filled. He praised past volunteers—“They may not be here, but they were when it counted”—and appealed, “We need your help. With it we can open up in December...one month at a time.” Longtime volunteer Melanie Keller echoed, “We are a community and I hope to see some of you as hosts,” encouraging more residents to join as hosts or overnight sleepers.

title: Police charge suspect in connection with Easton High bomb threat
author: STAFF REPORT
content: A 17-year-old female not enrolled in Talbot County Public Schools has been charged with “making a threat of mass violence” after calling Easton High, stating “there was a bomb inside of the school and hung up,” then phoning back to ask, “when dismissal was.” Sheriff Joe Gamble praised the rapid response: “I am so grateful for the outstanding work our Talbot Deputies, Easton Police Officers, and our Talbot County Department of Emergency Services Dispatchers performed today to identify the caller of the bomb threat,” and noted, “The teachers and staff at Easton High worked tirelessly with law enforcement to make sure everyone was safe. title: Talbot County man charged for possessing, distributing child porn
author: Konner Metz
content: Jordan Cabrera, 20, of Trappe was arrested March 2 and charged with two counts of soliciting a minor to engage as a subject in child porn and one count of knowingly distributing child porn, according to a Talbot County Sheriff’s Office release. Court records show the charges were filed by Cabrera’s ex-girlfriend, who wrote they broke up in 2023, a month before she turned 18, and stated she was a minor in every nude photo and video. She alleged Cabrera obtained the images from her while she was underage and distributed them on the messaging app Telegram, with the photos also surfacing on Instagram and Twitter. Cabrera was initially held without bond before posting $1,500 bond March 3; a preliminary hearing is set for March 31.

title: Anton Black's cause of death should be ruled homicide, audit finds
author: WENDY WEITZEL wweitzel@chespub.com
content: A state audit released Thursday reclassified Anton Black’s 2018 police-involved death from accidental to homicide and, in 36 of 87 cases reviewed, faulted former medical examiner Dr. David Fowler for using discredited concepts like “excited delirium.” Attorney General Anthony Brown said, “Addressing those concerns benefits everyone in our system of justice — including the vast majority of law enforcement professionals who perform their duties with integrity and deserve clear, consistent standards,” while Gov. Wes Moore called the report “the beginning of a long conversation — one that must be handled with honesty, delicacy, resolve, and deep consideration.” ACLU attorney Sonia Kumar added, “This 70-page independent report vindicates what family members and communities — mostly Black and Brown Marylanders — have been saying for decades: the truth. That the entire system has been complicit in making police-involved deaths seem inevitable.”

title: Counties and towns prepare for snow on the Mid-Shore this weekend
author: Maggie Trovato
content: As a “major winter storm” tracks “from the Central Plains to the Mid-Atlantic,” Easton crews have mounted plows, loaded salt and, as Town Engineer Rick Van Emburgh notes, positioned gear so that “we have equipment that we’re placing around town that we’ll use to address alleys and some of the tighter spots that we plow.” Officials urge residents to keep cars off streets—“When people park on the streets, we have to plow around the cars and sometimes that can — depending on how much snow we get — that can get tricky and then we plow the cars in”—and to shovel snow away from the roadway: “It’s just a battle. (Residents) plow it onto the street. We plow it back onto the sidewalk. And they get mad at us.” Dorchester’s Jimmy Windsor adds that households should prep vehicles, bundle up, and “have a supply of fresh water in case the power goes out and you’re on well water and therefore you rely on the power for your water source,” while Van Emburgh reminds that “some properties don’t have yards,” so snow pushed into the street merely cycles back: “But if you plow it out in the street, it’s just going to get pushed back onto the sidewalk. So we ask that everything moves away from the center of the street.”
